body:
Could this be related to #10720 which changed internal header handling in 8.0.2?
Note that the -X option in that command should be removed.
That seems likely. I assume you see different behaviour when adding `--http1.1`?

@icing yes, adding that is fixing the issue. 
As visible on the screenshot, `nghttp2` is different in those versions. So it's only happening with HTTP2.

We introduced a limit when we refactored the http2 code. Most servers I know have a limit on header length to protect themselves from malicious input.

Is this an experiment you are running or do you have a use case for such headers? If yes, what is the limit you are looking for?

I have discovered this, as libcurl is a downstream dependency of a library that I use in ([ethon](https://github.com/typhoeus/ethon))
It is a real life usecase, had to adjust what is being sent with the header. The limit I keep in mind always is one from aws alb - https://docs.aws.amazon.com/elasticloadbalancing/latest/application/load-balancer-limits.html
That would be a little over 15k characters.
I understand this might be quite the edge case, just wanted to bring this to attention, also in case somebody starts getting the error after updating from 8.0.1.
A number of popular web servers support up to 16KB headers (a few support even longer), so 16KB is probably a reasonable limit (if libcurl needs to limit them at all).

If it helps, below is result with Go `net/http`. I would say that the given server is a poor example, as it doesnt even handle the request as given:

- not quite to infinity
- refs #11405
- rewrote the implementation of our internal HTTP/1.x request parsing to work with very large lines using dynbufs.
- new default limit is `DYN_HTTP_REQUEST`, aka 1MB, which is also the limit of curl's general HTTP request processing.

body:
Thanks. I made #11407 just now which overcomes these limitations.

Curl internally has a general buffer limited to 1MB for assembling a HTTP request. This limit is now also in effect for HTTP/2 and HTTP/3 request processing with this PR.

issue.title: HTTP/2 connection uploads stall in 8.1.0 .. 8.1.2

repository.name: curl
repository.description: A command line tool and library for transferring data with URL syntax, supporting DICT, FILE, FTP, FTPS, GOPHER, GOPHERS, HTTP, HTTPS, IMAP, IMAPS, LDAP, LDAPS, MQTT, POP3, POP3S, RTMP, RTMPS, RTSP, SCP, SFTP, SMB, SMBS, SMTP, SMTPS, TELNET, TFTP, WS and WSS. libcurl offers a myriad of powerful features

issue.body:
### I did this

In tensorstore (http://github.com/google/tensorstore) we use curl for HTTP/2 uploads to GCS and other storage services. When trying to upgrade curl to 8.1.1 or later, uploads get stuck. 

This appears to trigger on a load-balanced server which closes the HTTP/2 connection. The client then leaves the connection in a CLOSE_WAIT state, which is never handled.

```
$ netstat -t
Active Internet connections (w/o servers)
Proto Recv-Q Send-Q Local Address           Foreign Address         State      
tcp        0      0 linux-repro.us-ce:44210 metadata.google.in:http ESTABLISHED
tcp        0      0 linux-repro.us-ce:44278 metadata.google.in:http ESTABLISHED
tcp        0      0 linux-repro.us-cent:ssh 172.217.41.166:38420    ESTABLISHED
tcp      200      0 linux-repro.us-ce:41612 il-in-f128.1e100.:https CLOSE_WAIT 
```

The process gets stuck with a backtrace in:

```
#0  0x00007fc0f05e596f in __GI___poll (fds=0x7fc0ed2eec00, nfds=1, timeout=2147483647) at ../sysdeps/unix/sysv/linux/poll.c:29
#1  0x00005642d1d8477d in Curl_poll.part.0 ()
#2  0x00005642d1d646bb in multi_wait.part ()
#3  0x00005642d1d64b99 in curl_multi_poll ()
#4  0x00005642d1d581e1 in std::thread::_State_impl<std::thread::_Invoker<std::tuple<tensorstore::internal::Thread::Thread<tensorstore::internal_http::(anonymous namespace)::MultiTransportImpl::MultiTransportImpl(std::shared_ptr<tensorstore::internal_http::CurlHandleFactory>)::{lambda()#2}>(tensorstore::internal::Thread::private_t, tensorstore::internal::Thread::Options, tensorstore::internal_http::(anonymous namespace)::MultiTransportImpl::MultiTransportImpl(std::shared_ptr<tensorstore::internal_http::CurlHandleFactory>)::{lambda()#2}&&)::{lambda()#1}> > >::_M_run() ()
#5  0x00007fc0f07b2ed0 in ?? () from /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libstdc++.so.6
#6  0x00007fc0f09fcea7 in start_thread (arg=<optimized out>) at pthread_create.c:477
#7  0x00007fc0f05f1a2f in clone () at ../sysdeps/unix/sysv/linux/x86_64/clone.S:95
```

Which suggests that the fd was removed from the multi handle and not properly cleaned up.

I haven't tested all the recent commits to see whether this is fixed at head; working on that.
It's a bit hard to isolate any change because http2.c underwent extensive changes in this period.
(https://github.com/curl/curl/compare/curl-8_0_1...curl-8_1_1)

### curl/libcurl version

Any libcurl release > 8.0.1 triggers.
Reliably triggers after commit  1886eef7fa0d75dba558fbcefa30e4ea9befde97

### operating system

Linux linux-repro 5.10.0-23-cloud-amd64 #1 SMP Debian 5.10.179-1 (2023-05-12) x86_64 GNU/Linux


### Repro script

Prerequisites:

```
# Install build reqs and change curl to 8.1.1
sudo apt-get install build-essential git unzip wget nasm python3 python3-dev python3-pip python3-venv bc jq ripgrep

git clone https://github.com/google/tensorstore.git
cd tensorstore

# By hand, update to use any reasonable git hash
#   H = "e0093b4b732f6495b0fb1cd6747cbfedcdcf63ed"
#   URL = "https://github.com/curl/curl/archive/" + H + ".tar.gz"
#
#  update urls, strip-prefix, etc.
vi third_party/se_curl/workspace.bzl

# Build tensorstore with curl debug logging enabled.
./bazelisk.py build --@se_curl//:debug -c dbg //tensorstore/internal/benchmark:kvstore_benchmark || exit 1
./bazelisk.py shutdown
```

Repro script:

```
# GDB script
#
# gdb --command=cmd.gdb tensorstore/bazel-bin/tensorstore/internal/benchmark/kvstore_benchmark
set pagination off

set environment TENSORSTORE_CURL_LOW_SPEED_TIME_SECONDS 60
set environment TENSORSTORE_CURL_LOW_SPEED_LIMIT_BYTES  256

unset environment TENSORSTORE_GCS_REQUEST_CONCURRENCY
# set environment TENSORSTORE_GCS_REQUEST_CONCURRENCY 4

unset environment TENSORSTORE_CURL_VERBOSE
# set environment TENSORSTORE_CURL_VERBOSE 1

# unset environment CURL_DEBUG
set environment CURL_DEBUG http/2,tcp

#break external/se_curl/src/lib/speedcheck.c:59
break speedcheck.c:59
  command 1
  bt
  print data
  print data->progress
end


# Run the kvstore_benchmark
run \
  --chunk_size=20971520 --total_bytes=10737418240 --repeat_reads=0 --repeat_writes=1000 \
  --kvstore_spec="\"gs://__bucket__/data\"" \
  --metric_kvstore_spec="\"gs://__bucket__/metrics/gdb\""

```

Ideally run under screen or use some other log capturing strategy.  The log may be very large (50GB), and it may take several hours on one machine.
